✅ Objective

Cut wires in the correct sequence, by clicking their corresponding boxes. If clicked out of order, trigger a failure (e.g., health drop or sound effect).

🧠 Assumptions

From the UI:

  • There are 8 wire terminals, indexed 1 to 8, each with its own bounding box.

✅ Step-by-Step Code Addition

1. Define wire click areas and state

Add this above main() or globally:

c
// Define bounding boxes for the wire terminals
// Format: {x1, y1, x2, y2}
int wireBoxes[8][4] = {
    {430,  50,  470,  120},  // Box 1
    {500,  50,  540,  120},  // Box 2
    {570,  50,  610,  120},  // Box 3
    {640,  50,  680,  120},  // Box 4
    {710,  50,  750,  120},  // Box 5
    {780,  50,  820,  120},  // Box 6
    {850,  50,  890,  120},  // Box 7
    {920,  50,  960,  120}   // Box 8
};

// Correct cut order of wire indices (0-based, e.g., wire 3 means box index 2)
int correctWireOrder[] = {5, 2, 6, 0, 4, 7, 3, 1}; // example order
int currentWireIndex = 0;
bool wireCut[8] = {false};
bool electrifiedPuzzleCompleted = false;
bool electrifiedPuzzleFailed = false;

2. Handle clicks in iMouse() when scene == 10

Modify your case 10: in iMouse() like this:

c
case 10:
    for (int i = 0; i < 8; i++) {
        if (!wireCut[i]) {
            if (mx >= wireBoxes[i][0] && mx <= wireBoxes[i][2] &&
                my >= wireBoxes[i][1] && my <= wireBoxes[i][3]) {
                
                if (i == correctWireOrder[currentWireIndex]) {
                    wireCut[i] = true;
                    currentWireIndex++;
                    iPlaySound("assets/sounds/cut.wav", false, 100);

                    if (currentWireIndex == 8) {
                        electrifiedPuzzleCompleted = true;
                        iPlaySound("assets/sounds/success.wav", false, 100);
                    }
                } else {
                    electrifiedPuzzleFailed = true;
                    iPlaySound("assets/sounds/error.wav", false, 100);
                }
                break;
            }
        }
    }
    break;

3. Visual Feedback in iDraw() (case 10)

Update your case 10: to reflect wire-cut or success/failure:

c
case 10:
    iShowLoadedImage(0, 0, &e);

    // Highlight cut wires
    for (int i = 0; i < 8; i++) {

                             wireBoxes[i][2] - wireBoxes[i][0],

    }

    if (electrifiedPuzzleFailed) {
        iSetColor(255, 0, 0);
        iText(500, 200, "Wrong Wire! Patient is in Danger!", GLUT_BITMAP_HELVETICA_18);
    }

    break;

There could be a few common issues causing your clicks to not register in scene 10 after updating the code. Let’s walk through a checklist to help you debug it:

✅ 1. Are the wire box coordinates in screen space?

In your game, you’re using a zoom ratio:

cpp
float ratio = 0.8;

So if your wire boxes are drawn without multiplying by ratio, but your click coordinates are raw, they won’t align properly.

✅ Fix: Multiply wire box coordinates by ratio

When checking clicks:

cpp
if (mx >= wireBoxes[i][0] * ratio && mx <= wireBoxes[i][2] * ratio &&
    my >= wireBoxes[i][1] * ratio && my <= wireBoxes[i][3] * ratio)

Alternatively, pre-scale the coordinates when defining wireBoxes.

✅ 2. Did you actually activate scene = 10 in-game?

Ensure your game is in scene 10 when testing the click. You can add a debug print to confirm:

cpp
printf("Mouse click at %d, %d in scene %d\n", mx, my, scene);

✅ 3. Did you add case 10: inside the switch(scene) in iMouse()?

Double-check your iMouse() function:

cpp

    if (button == GLUT_LEFT_BUTTON && state == GLUT_DOWN) {
        switch (scene) {
            case 10:
                // wire click logic here
                break;
        }
    }
}

✅ 4. Is the wireBoxes array correctly sized and indexed?

If your array wireBoxes is 8 x 4, make sure you:

  • Only access indices 0–7

  • Match your visual layout (from the image, you have 8 terminals, not 10)

✅ 5. Is something overlapping the clickable region?

If there's an image or shape that overlaps the wire boxes (e.g., a full image or transparent overlay), it may consume the click visually, making it look like nothing happens.

Try drawing a colored rectangle over each box for debugging:

cpp

                     (wireBoxes[i][3] - wireBoxes[i][1]) * ratio);

✅ 6. Are you drawing the click boxes at the same coordinates you're checking?

Your logic might be working, but the visual boxes could be mismatched.

Make sure the box you're checking matches the one on screen. You can do this temporarily by drawing the box you just clicked:

cpp
iSetColor(0, 255, 0);
iFilledRectangle(mx, my, 5, 5); // shows small green square at click point

✅ 7. Is the mouse callback registered properly?

If you moved the logic but didn't recompile fully or forgot to register the updated iMouse() function, it may still be using old behavior.

💾 Saving and Continuing

  • Your game automatically saves progress (name, score, level).

cpp
case 10:
    if (!electroPuzzleCompleted) {
        for (int i = 0; i < 8; i++) {
            if (wireMatched[i]) continue;

            // If no top box selected yet
            if (selectedTopBox == -1 &&
                mx >= wireBoxes[i][0] && mx <= wireBoxes[i][2] &&

                        electroPuzzleCompleted = true;
                        iPlaySound("assets/sounds/success.wav", false, 100);
                    }
                } else {
                    wireFailed = true;
                    iPlaySound("assets/sounds/error.wav", false, 100);
                    // reset
                    selectedTopBox = -1;
                    currentWireIndex = 0;
                    memset(wireMatched, false, sizeof(wireMatched));

                break;

    }

where is the problem?
ChatGPT said:

Great catch — the error is coming from misplaced break; and case labels in your iMouse() function.

🔴 What the error means:

a case label may only be used within a switch
a break statement may only be used within a loop or switch

This means:

  • You have case 10: or break; outside of any switch statement, which is invalid.

✅ What's the actual problem?

Looking at your screenshot (line 794 and above), it seems you accidentally have an extra break; or unmatched } in the iMouse() function.

Here's the relevant mistake (zooming in):

cpp
...
memset(wireMatched, false, sizeof(wireMatched));
}  // ← closes the for-loop
break;
}  // ← closes the if (!electroPuzzleCompleted) block
break; // ← ❌ This one is dangling — causes compile error!

You likely added an extra break; at line 794, which is not inside a switch or loop — hence the compiler is complaining.

✅ How to fix it:

  1. Remove the unnecessary break; outside the switch block.

  2. Make sure the structure is:

cpp
switch (scene) {
  case 10:
    if (!electroPuzzleCompleted) {
        for (...) {
            ...
        }
    }
    break;  // ✅ This is the correct break for `case 10`
}

So inside iMouse(), your scene 10 block should end like:

cpp
...
memset(wireMatched, false, sizeof(wireMatched));
} // end for
} // end if (!electroPuzzleCompleted)
break; // ✅ one break for case 10

🔁 Extra Tip:

Also, remove any floating case 10: that's commented or misplaced. You seem to have this old code block commented out but maybe still causing structure confusion:

cpp
/* case 10:
    for (...) {
        ...
    }
    break;
*/

Make sure it's fully commented or removed.
